title: Student Feedback: Adrian's Forest Environment
search_text: AVC200 December 03, 2025 Student Feedback: Adrian's Forest Environment is going to show us something about he has a cloud of stuff. might have been recording. >> Yeah. Yeah. He turned down his mic somehow. audio channel. Okay. It's got a real vibe to it. That's good. Um, the other thing, you may have seen the back and forth on Discord earlier. Um the uh B one one of B's interactables was like super it was the game was hanging when you walked into that um collider and you know this uh Bo had good instincts here but um each collider needs to be you know calculated here. Uh the computer needs to figure out like where is this shape in space and when another collider gets close it's not doing it every frame. there is like a you know like this this windowing that happens when it gets close then it starts figuring out like did they touch did they touch did they touch and so the this calculation gets much more uh much more complicated quickly when the shapes that we're testing are not regular shapes right spheres being the absolute easiest because this figuring out whether or not you're within a spherical radius is just very very basic trigonometry. As soon as you start doing any other more complicated shape uh especially a mesh that may have a very complicated shape with holes in it and indents and stuff then this calculation even for two meshes hitting each other becomes much more complicated. And so the main problem with Bose was that um he did have triggers that were box colliders, which is correct, but then he also had mesh colliders on like several objects that were nested within each other and they all turned on at the same time and that's what caused the uh just freeze essentially for almost like half a second. Uh, so there's pretty much I mean I can't think of a bunch of situations where you're going to want to have multiple colliders on one object if you find yourself doing that. Step back and ask, is this really the best way to go about this? Right? I mean, there's a handful of situations, you know, like our colliders without a trigger are primarily for physics stuff. you know, something's gonna fall over, if we're going to push it, whatever it is, right? Um, the trigger boxes most of the time, try to do it with a box or a sphere and then, you know, only if absolutely necessary, try to do it with something else there. But then, yeah, putting both of those on, like Bose's character walked into the area, and then it was like a parent object with a box and a mesh collider and then like three child objects that were within that collider that also had those two colliders on them. And so it was like trying to figure out like what's touching what. Everything was overlapping. And so that uh was the was the primary issue there. And the uh Bo added the mesh colliders because when he animated the he had like potions coming out of a chest and he wanted them to not he he used the animate script to move them but he wanted them to kind of like not hit the side of the chest. And his instinct here was to put a mesh collider so that it would force itself up and around. And that's just not how it's designed to work. You just want to animate it going up and out, right? And remember in the animate, you know, in the animate script, you can't have multiple tracks for multiple transform properties, right? So, animating it moving plus going up and down can animate going out. Uh, I put the screenshot of what that looks like on Discord over the weekend. Uh, it's somewhere Yeah. Here. Right. So, the position Y goes up and over and the position Z just goes off to the side. Right. And so, that um would be a hop there. But I'm sure he wasn't the only person running into that. just sort of he had a very condensed um version of that that was really tanking the performance for for a minute there. But once I removed the mesh colliders from the whole stack, then it worked fine. Everything else was was totally cool. So yeah, I mean I've tried, you know, the best possible here with the scripts to make sure that the default state isn't going to be something that's going to totally decrease performance, but you know, the possibility of adding stuff that does decrease performance is totally totally possible. So, uh, you being aware of that. One of them being multiple colliders per per thing is not not usually the way to go there. Okay,

Um, but yeah, I'm not expecting all of these processes to be foolproof, right?
